text: King David was old and advanced in years, and although they covered him with clothes, he could not get warm.
speaker: Narrator

text: So his servants said to him, “Let a young virgin be sought for my lord the king, and let her wait on the king and be his attendant; let her lie in your bosom, so that my lord the king may be warm.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they searched for a beautiful young woman throughout all the territory of Israel and found Abishag the Shunammite and brought her to the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: The young woman was very beautiful. She became the king’s attendant and served him, but the king did not know her sexually.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Adonijah son of Haggith exalted himself, saying, “I will be king.” He prepared for himself chariots and horsemen, and fifty men to run before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: His father had never at any time reprimanded him by asking, “Why have you done thus and so?” He was also a very handsome man, and he was born next after Absalom.
speaker: Narrator

text: He conferred with Joab son of Zeruiah and with the priest Abiathar, and they supported Adonijah.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the priest Zadok, and Benaiah son of Jehoiada, and the prophet Nathan, and Shammah and his companions, David’s own warriors, did not side with Adonijah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Adonijah sacrificed sheep, oxen, and fatted cattle by the stone Zoheleth, which is beside En-rogel, and he invited all his brothers, the king’s sons, and all the royal officials of Judah,
speaker: Narrator

text: but he did not invite the prophet Nathan or Benaiah or the warriors or his brother Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Nathan said to Bathsheba, Solomon’s mother, “Have you not heard that Adonijah son of Haggith has become king and our lord David does not know it?
speaker: Narrator

text: Now therefore come, let me give you advice, so that you may save your own life and the life of your son Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go in at once to King David and say to him, ‘Did you not, my lord the king, swear to your servant, saying, “Your son Solomon shall succeed me as king, and he shall sit on my throne? Why then is Adonijah king?” ’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then while you are still there speaking with the king, I will come in after you and confirm your words.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Bathsheba went to the king in his room. The king was very old; Abishag the Shunammite was attending the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bathsheba bowed and did obeisance to the king, and the king said, “What do you wish?”
speaker: Narrator

text: She said to him, “My lord, you swore to your servant by the Lord your God, saying, ‘Your son Solomon shall succeed me as king, and he shall sit on my throne.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But now suddenly Adonijah has become king, though you, my lord the king, do not know it.
speaker: Narrator

text: He has sacrificed oxen, fatted cattle, and sheep in abundance and has invited all the children of the king, the priest Abiathar, and Joab the commander of the army, but your servant Solomon he has not invited.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you, my lord the king, the eyes of all Israel are on you to tell them who shall sit on the throne of my lord the king after him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Otherwise it will come to pass, when my lord the king sleeps with his ancestors, that my son Solomon and I will be counted offenders.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While she was still speaking with the king, the prophet Nathan came in.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king was told, “Here is the prophet Nathan.” When he came in before the king, he did obeisance to the king, with his face to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nathan said, “My lord the king, have you said, ‘Adonijah shall succeed me as king, and he shall sit on my throne’?
speaker: Narrator

text: For today he has gone down and has sacrificed oxen, fatted cattle, and sheep in abundance and has invited all the king’s children, Joab the commander of the army, and the priest Abiathar, who are now eating and drinking before him, and saying, ‘Long live King Adonijah!’
speaker: Narrator

text: But he did not invite me, your servant, and the priest Zadok, and Benaiah son of Jehoiada, and your servant Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Has this thing been brought about by my lord the king and you have not let your servants know who should sit on the throne of my lord the king after him?”
speaker: Narrator

text: King David answered, “Summon Bathsheba to me.” So she came into the king’s presence and stood before the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king swore, saying, “As the Lord lives, who has saved my life from every adversity,
speaker: Narrator

text: as I swore to you by the Lord, the God of Israel, ‘Your son Solomon shall succeed me as king, and he shall sit on my throne in my place,’ so will I do this day.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Bathsheba bowed with her face to the ground and did obeisance to the king and said, “May my lord King David live forever!”
speaker: Narrator

text: King David said, “Summon to me the priest Zadok, the prophet Nathan, and Benaiah son of Jehoiada.” When they came before the king,
speaker: Narrator

text: the king said to them, “Take with you the servants of your lord and have my son Solomon ride on my own mule and bring him down to Gihon.
speaker: Narrator

text: There let the priest Zadok and the prophet Nathan anoint him king over Israel; then blow the trumpet and say, ‘Long live King Solomon!’
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall go up following him. Let him enter and sit on my throne; he shall be king in my place, for I have appointed him to be ruler over Israel and over Judah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Benaiah son of Jehoiada answered the king, “Amen! May the Lord, the God of my lord the king, so ordain.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the Lord has been with my lord the king, so may he be with Solomon and make his throne greater than the throne of my lord King David.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the priest Zadok, the prophet Nathan, Benaiah son of Jehoiada, and the Cherethites and the Pelethites went down and had Solomon ride on King David’s mule and led him to Gihon.
speaker: Narrator

text: There the priest Zadok took the horn of oil from the tent and anointed Solomon. Then they blew the trumpet, and all the people said, “Long live King Solomon!”
speaker: Narrator

text: And all the people went up following him, playing on pipes and rejoicing with great joy, so that the earth quaked at their noise.
speaker: Narrator

text: Adonijah and all the guests who were with him heard it as they finished feasting. When Joab heard the sound of the trumpet, he said, “Why is the city in an uproar?”
speaker: Narrator

text: While he was still speaking, Jonathan son of the priest Abiathar arrived. Adonijah said, “Come in, for you are a worthy man and surely you bring good news.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan answered Adonijah, “No, for our lord King David has made Solomon king;
speaker: Narrator

text: the king has sent with him the priest Zadok, the prophet Nathan, Benaiah son of Jehoiada, and the Cherethites and the Pelethites, and they had him ride on the king’s mule;
speaker: Narrator

text: the priest Zadok and the prophet Nathan have anointed him king at Gihon, and they have gone up from there rejoicing, so that the city is in an uproar. This is the noise that you heard.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon now sits on the royal throne.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, the king’s servants came to congratulate our lord King David, saying, ‘May God make the name of Solomon more famous than yours and make his throne greater than your throne.’ The king bowed in worship on the bed
speaker: Narrator

text: and went on to pray thus, ‘Blessed be the Lord, the God of Israel, who today has granted one of my offspring to sit on my throne and permitted me to witness it.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the guests of Adonijah got up trembling and went their own ways.
speaker: Narrator

text: Adonijah, fearing Solomon, got up and went to grasp the horns of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon was informed, “Adonijah is afraid of King Solomon; see, he has laid hold of the horns of the altar, saying, ‘Let King Solomon swear to me first that he will not kill his servant with the sword.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Solomon responded, “If he proves to be a worthy man, not one of his hairs shall fall to the ground, but if wickedness is found in him, he shall die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then King Solomon sent to have him brought down from the altar. He came to do obeisance to King Solomon, and Solomon said to him, “Go home.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When David’s time to die drew near, he charged his son Solomon, saying:
speaker: Narrator

text: “I am about to go the way of all the earth. Be strong, be courageous,
speaker: Narrator

text: and keep the charge of the Lord your God, walking in his ways and keeping his statutes, his commandments, his ordinances, and his testimonies, as it is written in the law of Moses, so that you may prosper in all that you do and wherever you turn.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord will establish his word that he spoke concerning me: ‘If your heirs take heed to their way, to walk before me in faithfulness with all their heart and with all their soul, there shall not fail you a successor on the throne of Israel.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Moreover, you know also what Joab son of Zeruiah did to me, how he dealt with the two commanders of the armies of Israel, Abner son of Ner and Amasa son of Jether, whom he murdered, retaliating in time of peace for blood that had been shed in war and putting innocent blood on the belt around my waist and on the sandals on my feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: Act, therefore, according to your wisdom, but do not let his gray head go down to Sheol in peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: Deal loyally, however, with the sons of Barzillai the Gileadite, and let them be among those who eat at your table, for with such loyalty they met me when I fled from your brother Absalom.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is also with you Shimei son of Gera, a Benjaminite from Bahurim, who cursed me with a terrible curse on the day when I went to Mahanaim, but when he came down to meet me at the Jordan, I swore to him by the Lord, ‘I will not put you to death with the sword.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore do not hold him guiltless, for you are a wise man; you will know what you ought to do to him, and you must bring his gray head down with blood to Sheol.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David slept with his ancestors and was buried in the city of David.
speaker: Narrator

text: The time that David reigned over Israel was forty years; he reigned seven years in Hebron and thirty-three years in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Solomon sat on the throne of his father David, and his kingdom was firmly established.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Adonijah son of Haggith came to Bathsheba, Solomon’s mother. She asked, “Do you come peaceably?” He said, “Peaceably.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said, “May I have a word with you?” She said, “Go on.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “You know that the kingdom was mine and that all Israel expected me to reign; however, the kingdom has turned about and become my brother’s, for it was his from the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: And now I have one request to make of you; do not refuse me.” She said to him, “Go on.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Please ask King Solomon—he will not refuse you—to give me Abishag the Shunammite as my wife.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Bathsheba said, “Very well; I will speak to the king on your behalf.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Bathsheba went to King Solomon, to speak to him on behalf of Adonijah. The king rose to meet her and bowed down to her; then he sat on his throne and had a throne brought for the king’s mother, and she sat on his right.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she said, “I have one small request to make of you; do not refuse me.” And the king said to her, “Make your request, my mother, for I will not refuse you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She said, “Let Abishag the Shunammite be given to your brother Adonijah as his wife.”
speaker: Narrator

text: King Solomon answered his mother, “And why do you ask Abishag the Shunammite for Adonijah? Ask for him the kingdom as well! For he is my elder brother, and the priest Abiathar and Joab son of Zeruiah are on his side!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then King Solomon swore by the Lord, “So may God do to me, and more also, for Adonijah has devised this scheme at the risk of his life!
speaker: Narrator

text: Now therefore as the Lord lives, who has established me and placed me on the throne of my father David and who has made me a house as he promised, today Adonijah shall be put to death.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So King Solomon sent Benaiah son of Jehoiada; he struck him down, and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said to the priest Abiathar, “Go to Anathoth, to your estate, for you deserve death. But I will not at this time put you to death because you carried the ark of the Lord God before my father David and because you shared in all the hardships my father endured.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Solomon banished Abiathar from being priest to the Lord, thus fulfilling the word of the Lord that he had spoken concerning the house of Eli in Shiloh.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the news came to Joab—for Joab had supported Adonijah though he had not supported Absalom—Joab fled to the tent of the Lord and grasped the horns of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: When it was told King Solomon, “Joab has fled to the tent of the Lord and now is beside the altar,” Solomon sent Benaiah son of Jehoiada, saying, “Go, strike him down.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Benaiah came to the tent of the Lord and said to him, “The king commands, ‘Come out.’ ” But he said, “No, I will die here.” Then Benaiah brought the king word again, saying, “Thus said Joab, and thus he answered me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king replied to him, “Do as he has said, strike him down and bury him, and thus take away from me and from my father’s house the guilt for the blood that Joab shed without cause.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will bring back his bloody deeds on his own head because, without the knowledge of my father David, he attacked and killed with the sword two men more righteous and better than he: Abner son of Ner, commander of the army of Israel, and Amasa son of Jether, commander of the army of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: So shall their blood come back on the head of Joab and on the head of his descendants forever, but to David, and to his descendants, and to his house, and to his throne there shall be peace from the Lord forevermore.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Benaiah son of Jehoiada went up and struck him down and killed him, and he was buried at his own house near the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king put Benaiah son of Jehoiada over the army in his place, and the king put the priest Zadok in the place of Abiathar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king sent and summoned Shimei and said to him, “Build yourself a house in Jerusalem and live there, and do not go out from there to any place whatever.
speaker: Narrator

text: For on the day you go out and cross the Wadi Kidron, know for certain that you shall die; your blood shall be on your own head.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Shimei said to the king, “The sentence is fair; as my lord the king has said, so will your servant do.” So Shimei lived in Jerusalem many days.
speaker: Narrator

text: But it happened at the end of three years that two of Shimei’s slaves ran away to King Achish son of Maacah of Gath. When it was told Shimei, “Your slaves are in Gath,”
speaker: Narrator

text: Shimei arose and saddled a donkey and went to Achish in Gath, to search for his slaves; Shimei went and brought his slaves from Gath.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Solomon was told that Shimei had gone from Jerusalem to Gath and returned,
speaker: Narrator

text: the king sent and summoned Shimei and said to him, “Did I not make you swear by the Lord and solemnly adjure you, saying, ‘Know for certain that on the day you go out and go to any place whatever, you shall die’? And you said to me, ‘The sentence is fair; I accept.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Why then have you not kept your oath to the Lord and the commandment with which I charged you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king also said to Shimei, “You know in your own heart all the evil that you did to my father David, so the Lord will bring back your evil on your own head.
speaker: Narrator

text: But King Solomon shall be blessed, and the throne of David shall be established before the Lord forever.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the king commanded Benaiah son of Jehoiada, and he went out and struck him down, and he died.
So the kingdom was established in the hand of Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon made a marriage alliance with Pharaoh king of Egypt; he took Pharaoh’s daughter and brought her into the city of David until he had finished building his own house and the house of the Lord and the wall around Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people were sacrificing at the high places, however, because no house had yet been built for the name of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon loved the Lord, walking in the statutes of his father David, except that he sacrificed and offered incense at the high places.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king went to Gibeon to sacrifice there, for that was the principal high place; Solomon used to offer a thousand burnt offerings on that altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: At Gibeon the Lord appeared to Solomon in a dream by night, and God said, “Ask what I should give you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Solomon said, “You have shown great and steadfast love to your servant my father David because he walked before you in faithfulness, in righteousness, and in uprightness of heart toward you, and you have kept for him this great and steadfast love and have given him a son to sit on his throne today.
speaker: Narrator

text: And now, O Lord my God, you have made your servant king in place of my father David, although I am only a little child; I do not know how to go out or come in.
speaker: Narrator

text: And your servant is in the midst of the people whom you have chosen, a great people so numerous they cannot be numbered or counted.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give your servant, therefore, an understanding mind to govern your people, able to discern between good and evil, for who can govern this great people of yours?”
speaker: Narrator

text: It pleased the Lord that Solomon had asked this.
speaker: Narrator

text: God said to him, “Because you have asked this and have not asked for yourself long life or riches or for the life of your enemies but have asked for yourself understanding to discern what is right,
speaker: Narrator

text: I now do according to your word. Indeed, I give you a wise and discerning mind; no one like you has been before you, and no one like you shall arise after you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I give you also what you have not asked, both riches and honor all your life; no other king shall compare with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you will walk in my ways, keeping my statutes and my commandments, as your father David walked, then I will lengthen your life.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Solomon awoke; it had been a dream. He came to Jerusalem, where he stood before the ark of the covenant of the Lord. He offered up burnt offerings and offerings of well-being and provided a feast for all his servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, two women who were prostitutes came to the king and stood before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The one woman said, “Please, my lord, this woman and I live in the same house, and I gave birth while she was in the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then on the third day after I gave birth, this woman also gave birth. We were together; there was no one else with us in the house; only the two of us were in the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then this woman’s son died in the night because she lay on him.
speaker: Narrator

text: She got up in the middle of the night and took my son from beside me while your servant slept. She laid him at her breast and laid her dead son at my breast.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I rose in the morning to nurse my son, I saw that he was dead, but when I looked at him closely in the morning, clearly it was not the son I had borne.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the other woman said, “No, the living son is mine, and the dead son is yours.” The first said, “No, the dead son is yours, and the living son is mine.” So they argued before the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king said, “The one says, ‘This is my son who is alive, and your son is dead,’ while the other says, ‘Not so! Your son is dead, and my son is the living one.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king said, “Bring me a sword,” and they brought a sword before the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said, “Divide the living boy in two; then give half to the one and half to the other.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the woman whose son was alive said to the king, because compassion for her son burned within her, “Please, my lord, give her the living boy; certainly do not kill him!” The other said, “It shall be neither mine nor yours; divide it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king responded, “Give her the living boy; do not kill him. She is his mother.”
speaker: Narrator

text: All Israel heard of the judgment that the king had rendered, and they stood in awe of the king because they perceived that the wisdom of God was in him to execute justice.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Solomon was king over all Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text: and these were his high officials: Azariah son of Zadok was the priest;
speaker: Narrator

text: Elihoreph and Ahijah sons of Shisha were secretaries; Jehoshaphat son of Ahilud was recorder;
speaker: Narrator

text: Benaiah son of Jehoiada was in command of the army; Zadok and Abiathar were priests;
speaker: Narrator

text: Azariah son of Nathan was over the officials; Zabud son of Nathan was priest and king’s friend;
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahishar was in charge of the palace; and Adoniram son of Abda was in charge of the forced labor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon had twelve officials over all Israel who provided food for the king and his household; each one had to make provision for one month in the year.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were their names: Ben-hur, in the hill country of Ephraim;
speaker: Narrator

text: Ben-deker, in Makaz, Shaalbim, Beth-shemesh, and Elon-beth-hanan;
speaker: Narrator

text: Ben-hesed, in Arubboth (to him belonged Socoh and all the land of Hepher);
speaker: Narrator

text: Ben-abinadab, in all Naphath-dor (he had Taphath, Solomon’s daughter, as his wife);
speaker: Narrator

text: Baana son of Ahilud, in Taanach, Megiddo, and all Beth-shean, which is beside Zarethan below Jezreel, and from Beth-shean to Abel-meholah, as far as the other side of Jokmeam;
speaker: Narrator

text: Ben-geber, in Ramoth-gilead (he had the villages of Jair son of Manasseh, which are in Gilead, and he had the region of Argob, which is in Bashan, sixty great cities with walls and bronze bars);
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahinadab son of Iddo, in Mahanaim;
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahimaaz, in Naphtali (he had taken Basemath, Solomon’s daughter, as his wife);
speaker: Narrator

text: Baana son of Hushai, in Asher and Bealoth;
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoshaphat son of Paruah, in Issachar;
speaker: Narrator

text: Shimei son of Ela, in Benjamin;
speaker: Narrator

text: Geber son of Uri, in the land of Gilead, the country of King Sihon of the Amorites and of King Og of Bashan. And there was one garrison in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah and Israel were as numerous as the sand by the sea; they ate and drank and were happy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon was sovereign over all the kingdoms from the Euphrates to the land of the Philistines, even to the border of Egypt; they brought tribute and served Solomon all the days of his life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon’s provision for one day was thirty cors of choice flour and sixty cors of meal,
speaker: Narrator

text: ten fat oxen and twenty pasture-fed cattle, one hundred sheep, besides deer, gazelles, roebucks, and fatted fowl.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he had dominion over all the region west of the Euphrates, and he had peace on all sides.
speaker: Narrator

text: During Solomon’s lifetime Judah and Israel lived in safety, from Dan even to Beer-sheba, all of them under their vines and fig trees.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon also had forty thousand stalls of horses for his chariots and twelve thousand horsemen.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those officials supplied provisions for King Solomon and for all who came to King Solomon’s table, each one in his month; they let nothing be lacking.
speaker: Narrator

text: They also brought to the required place barley and straw for the horses and swift steeds, each according to his charge.
speaker: Narrator

text: God gave Solomon very great wisdom, discernment, and breadth of understanding as vast as the sand on the seashore,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that Solomon’s wisdom surpassed the wisdom of all the people of the East and all the wisdom of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was wiser than anyone else, wiser than Ethan the Ezrahite and Heman, Calcol, and Darda, children of Mahol; his fame spread throughout all the surrounding nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: He composed three thousand proverbs, and his songs numbered a thousand and five.
speaker: Narrator

text: He would speak of trees, from the cedar that is in the Lebanon to the hyssop that grows in the wall; he would speak of animals, and birds, and reptiles, and fish.
speaker: Narrator

text: People came from all the nations to hear the wisdom of Solomon, from all the kings of the earth who had heard of his wisdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now King Hiram of Tyre sent his servants to Solomon when he heard that they had anointed him king in place of his father, for Hiram had always been a friend to David.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon sent word to Hiram, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “You know that my father David could not build a house for the name of the Lord his God because of the warfare with which his enemies surrounded him, until he put them under the soles of his feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now the Lord my God has given me rest on every side; there is neither adversary nor misfortune.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I intend to build a house for the name of the Lord my God, as the Lord said to my father David, ‘Your son, whom I will set on your throne in your place, shall build the house for my name.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore command that cedars from the Lebanon be cut for me. My servants will join your servants, and I will give you whatever wages you set for your servants, for you know that there is no one among us who knows how to cut timber like the Sidonians.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Hiram heard the words of Solomon, he rejoiced greatly and said, “Blessed be the Lord today, who has given to David a wise son to be over this great people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Hiram sent word to Solomon, “I have heard the message that you have sent to me; I will fulfill all your needs in the matter of cedar and cypress timber.
speaker: Narrator

text: My servants shall bring it down to the sea from the Lebanon; I will make it into rafts to go by sea to the place you indicate. I will have them broken up there for you to take away. And you shall meet my needs by providing food for my household.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Hiram supplied Solomon’s every need for timber of cedar and cypress.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon, in turn, gave Hiram twenty thousand cors of wheat as food for his household and twenty cors of fine oil. Solomon gave this to Hiram year by year.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord gave Solomon wisdom, as he had promised him. There was peace between Hiram and Solomon, and the two of them made a treaty.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Solomon conscripted forced labor out of all Israel; the levy numbered thirty thousand men.
speaker: Narrator

text: He sent them to the Lebanon, ten thousand a month in shifts; they would be a month in the Lebanon and two months at home; Adoniram was in charge of the forced labor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon also had seventy thousand laborers and eighty thousand stonecutters in the hill country,
speaker: Narrator

text: besides Solomon’s three thousand three hundred supervisors who were over the work, having charge of the people who did the work.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the king’s command, they quarried out great, costly stones in order to lay the foundation of the house with dressed stones.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Solomon’s builders and Hiram’s builders and the Gebalites did the stonecutting and prepared the timber and the stone to build the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the four hundred eightieth year after the Israelites came out of the land of Egypt, in the fourth year of Solomon’s reign over Israel, in the month of Ziv, which is the second month, he began to build the house of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The house that King Solomon built for the Lord was sixty cubits long, twenty cubits wide, and thirty cubits high.
speaker: Narrator

text: The vestibule in front of the nave of the house was twenty cubits wide, across the width of the house. Its depth was ten cubits in front of the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the house he made windows with recessed frames.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also built a structure against the wall of the house, running around the walls of the house, both the nave and the inner sanctuary, and he made side chambers all around.
speaker: Narrator

text: The lowest story was five cubits wide, the middle one was six cubits wide, and the third was seven cubits wide, for around the outside of the house he made offsets on the wall in order that the supporting beams should not be inserted into the walls of the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: The house was built with stone finished at the quarry so that neither hammer nor ax nor any tool of iron was heard in the temple while it was being built.
speaker: Narrator

text: The entrance for the lower story was on the south side of the house: one went up by winding stairs to the middle story and from the middle story to the third.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he built the house and finished it; he roofed the house with beams and planks of cedar.
speaker: Narrator

text: He built the structure against the whole house, each story five cubits high, and it was joined to the house with timbers of cedar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the word of the Lord came to Solomon,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Concerning this house that you are building, if you will walk in my statutes, obey my ordinances, and keep all my commandments by walking in them, then I will establish my promise with you that I made to your father David.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will dwell among the Israelites and will not forsake my people Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Solomon built the house and finished it.
speaker: Narrator

text: He lined the walls of the house on the inside with boards of cedar; from the floor of the house to the rafters of the ceiling, he covered them on the inside with wood, and he covered the floor of the house with boards of cypress.
speaker: Narrator

text: He built twenty cubits of the rear of the house with boards of cedar from the floor to the rafters, and he built this within as an inner sanctuary, as the most holy place.
speaker: Narrator

text: The house, that is, the nave in front of the inner sanctuary, was forty cubits long.
speaker: Narrator

text: The cedar within the house had carvings of gourds and open flowers; all was cedar; no stone was seen.
speaker: Narrator

text: The inner sanctuary he prepared in the innermost part of the house, to set there the ark of the covenant of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The interior of the inner sanctuary was twenty cubits long, twenty cubits wide, and twenty cubits high; he overlaid it with pure gold. He also overlaid the altar with cedar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon overlaid the inside of the house with pure gold, then he drew chains of gold across, in front of the inner sanctuary, and overlaid it with gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next he overlaid the whole house with gold, in order that the whole house might be perfect; even the whole altar that belonged to the inner sanctuary he overlaid with gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the inner sanctuary he made two cherubim of olivewood, each ten cubits high.
speaker: Narrator

text: Five cubits was the length of one wing of the cherub and five cubits the length of the other wing of the cherub; it was ten cubits from the tip of one wing to the tip of the other.
speaker: Narrator

text: The other cherub also measured ten cubits; both cherubim had the same measure and the same form.
speaker: Narrator

text: The height of one cherub was ten cubits, and so was that of the other cherub.
speaker: Narrator

text: He put the cherubim in the innermost part of the house; the wings of the cherubim were spread out so that a wing of one was touching the one wall and a wing of the other cherub was touching the other wall; their other wings toward the center of the house were touching wing to wing.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also overlaid the cherubim with gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: He carved the walls of the house all around about with carved engravings of cherubim, palm trees, and open flowers, in the inner and outer rooms.
speaker: Narrator

text: The floor of the house he overlaid with gold, in the inner and outer rooms.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the entrance to the inner sanctuary he made doors of olivewood; the lintel and the doorposts were five-sided.
speaker: Narrator

text: He covered the two doors of olivewood with carvings of cherubim, palm trees, and open flowers; he overlaid them with gold and spread gold on the cherubim and on the palm trees.
speaker: Narrator

text: So also he made for the entrance to the nave doorposts of olivewood, four-sided each,
speaker: Narrator

text: and two doors of cypress wood; the two leaves of the one door were folding, and the two leaves of the other door were folding.
speaker: Narrator

text: He carved cherubim, palm trees, and open flowers, overlaying them with gold evenly applied upon the carved work.
speaker: Narrator

text: He built the inner court with three courses of dressed stone to one course of cedar beams.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fourth year the foundation of the house of the Lord was laid, in the month of Ziv.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the eleventh year, in the month of Bul, which is the eighth month, the house was finished in all its parts and according to all its specifications. He was seven years in building it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon was building his own house thirteen years, and he finished his entire house.
speaker: Narrator

text: He built the House of the Forest of the Lebanon one hundred cubits long, fifty cubits wide, and thirty cubits high, built on four rows of cedar pillars, with cedar beams on the pillars.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was roofed with cedar on the forty-five rafters, fifteen in each row, which were on the pillars.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were window frames in the three rows, facing each other in the three rows.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the doorways and doorposts had four-sided frames, opposite, facing each other in the three rows.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made the Hall of Pillars fifty cubits long and thirty cubits wide. There was a porch in front with pillars and a canopy in front of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made the Hall of the Throne where he was to pronounce judgment, the Hall of Justice, covered with cedar from the floor to the rafters.
speaker: Narrator

text: His own house where he would reside, in the other court back of the hall, was of the same construction. Solomon also made a house like this hall for Pharaoh’s daughter, whom he had taken in marriage.
speaker: Narrator

text: All these were made of costly stones, cut according to measure, sawed with saws, back and front, from the foundation to the coping and from outside to the great court.
speaker: Narrator

text: The foundation was of costly stones, huge stones, stones of eight and ten cubits.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were costly stones above, cut to measure, and cedarwood.
speaker: Narrator

text: The great court had three courses of dressed stone to one layer of cedar beams all around; so had the inner court of the house of the Lord and the vestibule of the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now King Solomon invited and received Hiram from Tyre.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was the son of a widow of the tribe of Naphtali, whose father, a man of Tyre, had been an artisan in bronze; he was full of skill, intelligence, and knowledge in working bronze. He came to King Solomon and did all his work.
speaker: Narrator

text: He cast two pillars of bronze. Eighteen cubits was the height of the one, and a cord of twelve cubits would encircle it; the second pillar was the same.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also made two capitals of molten bronze to set on the tops of the pillars; the height of the one capital was five cubits, and the height of the other capital was five cubits.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were nets of checker work with wreaths of chain work for the capitals on the tops of the pillars, seven for the one capital and seven for the other capital.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made the columns with two rows around each latticework to cover the capitals that were above the pomegranates; he did the same with the other capital.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the capitals that were on the tops of the pillars in the vestibule were of lily-work, four cubits high.
speaker: Narrator

text: The capitals were on the two pillars and also above the rounded projection that was beside the latticework; there were two hundred pomegranates in rows all around, and so with the other capital.
speaker: Narrator

text: He set up the pillars at the vestibule of the temple; he set up the pillar on the south and called it Jachin, and he set up the pillar on the north and called it Boaz.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the tops of the pillars was lily-work. Thus the work of the pillars was finished.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he made the molten sea; it was round, ten cubits from brim to brim, and five cubits high. A line of thirty cubits would encircle it completely.
speaker: Narrator

text: Under its brim were gourds all around it, each of ten cubits, surrounding the sea; there were two rows of gourds, cast when it was cast.
speaker: Narrator

text: It stood on twelve oxen, three facing north, three facing west, three facing south, and three facing east; the sea was set on them. The hindquarters of each were toward the inside.
speaker: Narrator

text: Its thickness was a handbreadth; its brim was made like the brim of a cup, like the flower of a lily; it held two thousand baths.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also made the ten stands of bronze; each stand was four cubits long, four cubits wide, and three cubits high.
speaker: Narrator

text: This was the construction of the stands: they had borders; the borders were within the frames;
speaker: Narrator

text: on the borders that were set in the frames were lions, oxen, and cherubim. On the frames, both above and below the lions and oxen, there were wreaths of beveled work.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each stand had four bronze wheels and axles of bronze; at the four corners were supports for a basin. The supports were cast with wreaths at the side of each.
speaker: Narrator

text: Its opening was within the crown, whose height was one cubit; its opening was round, as a pedestal is made; it was a cubit and a half wide. At its opening there were carvings; its borders were four-sided, not round.
speaker: Narrator

text: The four wheels were underneath the borders; the axles of the wheels were in the stands; and the height of a wheel was a cubit and a half.
speaker: Narrator

text: The wheels were made like a chariot wheel; their axles, their rims, their spokes, and their hubs were all cast.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were four supports at the four corners of each stand; the supports were of one piece with the stands.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the top of the stand there was a round band half a cubit high; on the top of the stand, its stays and its borders were of one piece with it.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the surfaces of its stays and on its borders he carved cherubim, lions, and palm trees where each had space, with wreaths all around.
speaker: Narrator

text: In this way he made the ten stands; all of them were cast alike, with the same size and the same form.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made ten basins of bronze; each basin held forty baths; each basin measured four cubits; there was a basin for each of the ten stands.
speaker: Narrator

text: He set five of the stands on the south side of the house and five on the north side of the house; he set the sea on the southeast corner of the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hiram also made the pots, the shovels, and the basins. So Hiram finished all the work that he did for King Solomon on the house of the Lord:
speaker: Narrator

text: the two pillars, the two bowls of the capitals that were on the tops of the pillars, the two latticeworks to cover the two bowls of the capitals that were on the tops of the pillars;
speaker: Narrator

text: the four hundred pomegranates for the two latticeworks, two rows of pomegranates for each latticework, to cover the two bowls of the capitals that were on the pillars;
speaker: Narrator

text: the ten stands, the ten basins on the stands;
speaker: Narrator

text: the one sea and the twelve oxen underneath the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: The pots, the shovels, and the basins—all these vessels that Hiram made for King Solomon for the house of the Lord were of burnished bronze.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the plain of the Jordan the king cast them, in the clay ground between Succoth and Zarethan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon left all the vessels unweighed because there were so many of them; the weight of the bronze was not determined.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Solomon made all the vessels that were in the house of the Lord: the golden altar, the golden table for the bread of the Presence,
speaker: Narrator

text: the lampstands of pure gold, five on the south side and five on the north, in front of the inner sanctuary; the flowers, the lamps, and the tongs, of gold;
speaker: Narrator

text: the cups, snuffers, basins, dishes for incense, and firepans, of pure gold; the sockets for the doors of the innermost part of the house, the most holy place, and for the doors of the main hall of the temple, of gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus all the work that King Solomon did on the house of the Lord was finished. Solomon brought in the things that his father David had dedicated, the silver, the gold, and the vessels, and stored them in the treasuries of the house of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Solomon assembled the elders of Israel and all the heads of the tribes, the leaders of the ancestral houses of the Israelites, before King Solomon in Jerusalem, to bring up the ark of the covenant of the Lord out of the city of David, which is Zion.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people of Israel assembled to King Solomon at the festival in the month Ethanim, which is the seventh month.
speaker: Narrator

text: And all the elders of Israel came, and the priests carried the ark.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they brought up the ark of the Lord, the tent of meeting, and all the holy vessels that were in the tent; the priests and the Levites brought them up.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Solomon and all the congregation of Israel, who had assembled before him, were with him before the ark, sacrificing so many sheep and oxen that they could not be counted or numbered.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the priests brought the ark of the covenant of the Lord to its place, in the inner sanctuary of the house, the most holy place, underneath the wings of the cherubim.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the cherubim spread out their wings over the place of the ark, so that the cherubim made a covering above the ark and its poles.
speaker: Narrator

text: The poles were so long that the ends of the poles were seen from the holy place in front of the inner sanctuary, but they could not be seen from outside; they are there to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was nothing in the ark except the two tablets of stone that Moses had placed there at Horeb, where the Lord made a covenant with the Israelites when they came out of the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when the priests came out of the holy place, a cloud filled the house of the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that the priests could not stand to minister because of the cloud, for the glory of the Lord filled the house of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Solomon said,
“The Lord has said that he would dwell in thick darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have built you an exalted house,
    a place for you to dwell forever.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king turned around and blessed all the assembly of Israel, while all the assembly of Israel stood.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “Blessed be the Lord, the God of Israel, who with his hand has fulfilled what he promised with his mouth to my father David, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Since the day that I brought my people Israel out of Egypt, I have not chosen a city from any of the tribes of Israel in which to build a house, that my name might be there, nor did I choose anyone to be a ruler over my people Israel. But I have chosen Jerusalem in order that my name may be there, and I have chosen David to be over my people Israel.’
speaker: Narrator

text: My father David had it in mind to build a house for the name of the Lord, the God of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord said to my father David, ‘You did well to consider building a house for my name;
speaker: Narrator

text: nevertheless, you shall not build the house, but your son who shall be born to you shall build the house for my name.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Lord has fulfilled the promise that he made, for I have risen in the place of my father David; I sit on the throne of Israel, as the Lord promised, and have built the house for the name of the Lord, the God of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: There I have provided a place for the ark, in which is the covenant of the Lord that he made with our ancestors when he brought them out of the land of Egypt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Solomon stood before the altar of the Lord in the presence of the whole assembly of Israel and spread out his hands to heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “O Lord, God of Israel, there is no God like you in heaven above or on earth beneath, keeping covenant and steadfast love with your servants who walk before you with all their heart,
speaker: Narrator

text: the covenant that you kept for your servant my father David as you declared to him; you promised with your mouth and have this day fulfilled with your hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, O Lord, God of Israel, keep for your servant my father David that which you promised him, saying, ‘There shall never fail you a successor before me to sit on the throne of Israel, if only your children look to their way, to walk before me as you have walked before me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, O God of Israel, let your word be confirmed that you promised to your servant my father David.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But will God indeed dwell on the earth? Even heaven and the highest heaven cannot contain you, much less this house that I have built!
speaker: Narrator

text: Regard your servant’s prayer and his plea, O Lord my God, heeding the cry and the prayer that your servant prays to you today,
speaker: Narrator

text: that your eyes may be open night and day toward this house, the place of which you said, ‘My name shall be there,’ that you may heed the prayer that your servant prays toward this place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hear the plea of your servant and of your people Israel when they pray toward this place; O hear in heaven your dwelling place; hear and forgive.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If someone sins against a neighbor and is required to take an oath and comes and swears before your altar in this house,
speaker: Narrator

text: then hear in heaven, and act, and judge your servants, condemning the guilty by bringing their conduct on their own heads and vindicating the righteous by rewarding them according to their righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When your people Israel, having sinned against you, are defeated before an enemy but turn again to you, confess your name, pray and plead with you in this house,
speaker: Narrator

text: then hear in heaven, forgive the sin of your people Israel, and bring them again to the land that you gave to their ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When heaven is shut up and there is no rain because they have sinned against you and then they pray toward this place, confess your name, and turn from their sin because you punish them,
speaker: Narrator

text: then hear in heaven and forgive the sin of your servants, your people Israel, when you teach them the good way in which they should walk, and grant rain on your land, which you have given to your people as an inheritance.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If there is famine in the land, if there is plague, blight, mildew, locust, or caterpillar; if their enemy besieges them in any of their cities; whatever suffering, whatever sickness there is;
speaker: Narrator

text: whatever prayer, whatever plea there is from any individual or from all your people Israel, all knowing the suffering of their own hearts so that they stretch out their hands toward this house;
speaker: Narrator

text: then hear in heaven your dwelling place, forgive, act, and render to all whose hearts you know—according to all their ways, for only you know the human heart—
speaker: Narrator

text: so that they may fear you all the days that they live in the land that you gave to our ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Likewise when foreigners, who are not of your people Israel, come from a distant land because of your name
speaker: Narrator

text: —for they shall hear of your great name, your mighty hand, and your outstretched arm—when foreigners come and pray toward this house,
speaker: Narrator

text: then hear in heaven your dwelling place and do whatever the foreigners ask of you, so that all the peoples of the earth may know your name and fear you, as do your people Israel, and so they may know that your name has been invoked on this house that I have built.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If your people go out to battle against their enemy, by whatever way you shall send them, and they pray to the Lord toward the city that you have chosen and the house that I have built for your name,
speaker: Narrator

text: then hear in heaven their prayer and their plea and maintain their cause.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If they sin against you—for there is no one who does not sin—and you are angry with them and give them to an enemy, so that they are carried away captive to the land of the enemy, far off or near,
speaker: Narrator

text: then if they come to their senses in the land to which they have been taken captive and repent and plead with you in the land of their captors, saying, ‘We have sinned and have done wrong; we have acted wickedly,’
speaker: Narrator

text: if they repent with all their heart and soul in the land of their enemies who took them captive and pray to you toward their land that you gave to their ancestors, the city that you have chosen, and the house that I have built for your name,
speaker: Narrator

text: then hear in heaven your dwelling place their prayer and their plea, maintain their cause,
speaker: Narrator

text: and forgive your people who have sinned against you and all their transgressions that they have committed against you, and grant them compassion in the sight of their captors, so that they may have compassion on them
speaker: Narrator

text: (for they are your people and heritage that you brought out of Egypt, from the midst of the iron smelter).
speaker: Narrator

text: Let your eyes be open to the plea of your servant and to the plea of your people Israel, listening to them whenever they call to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: For you have separated them from among all the peoples of the earth to be your heritage, just as you promised through Moses, your servant, when you brought our ancestors out of Egypt, O Lord God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when Solomon finished offering all this prayer and this plea to the Lord, he arose from facing the altar of the Lord, where he had knelt with hands outstretched toward heaven;
speaker: Narrator

text: he stood and blessed all the assembly of Israel with a loud voice:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Blessed be the Lord, who has given rest to his people Israel according to all that he promised; not one word has failed of all his good promise that he spoke through his servant Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord our God be with us, as he was with our ancestors; may he not leave us or abandon us,
speaker: Narrator

text: but incline our hearts to him, to walk in all his ways and to keep his commandments, his statutes, and his ordinances that he commanded our ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let these words of mine, with which I pleaded before the Lord, be near to the Lord our God day and night, and may he maintain the cause of his servant and the cause of his people Israel, as each day requires,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that all the peoples of the earth may know that the Lord is God; there is no other.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore devote yourselves completely to the Lord our God, walking in his statutes and keeping his commandments, as at this day.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king and all Israel with him offered sacrifice before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon offered as sacrifices of well-being to the Lord twenty-two thousand oxen and one hundred twenty thousand sheep. So the king and all the people of Israel dedicated the house of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The same day the king consecrated the middle of the court that was in front of the house of the Lord, for there he offered the burnt offerings and the grain offerings and the fat pieces of the sacrifices of well-being, because the bronze altar that was before the Lord was too small to receive the burnt offerings and the grain offerings and the fat pieces of the sacrifices of well-being.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Solomon held the festival at that time and all Israel with him—a great assembly, people from Lebo-hamath to the Wadi of Egypt—before the Lord our God, seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the eighth day he sent the people away, and they blessed the king and went to their tents joyful and in good spirits because of all the goodness that the Lord had shown to his servant David and to his people Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Solomon had finished building the house of the Lord and the king’s house and all that Solomon desired to build,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Lord appeared to Solomon a second time, as he had appeared to him at Gibeon.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to him, “I have heard your prayer and your plea that you made before me; I have consecrated this house that you have built and put my name there forever; my eyes and my heart will be there for all time.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for you, if you will walk before me as David your father walked, with integrity of heart and uprightness, doing according to all that I have commanded you and keeping my statutes and my ordinances,
speaker: Narrator

text: then I will establish your royal throne over Israel forever, as I promised your father David, saying, ‘You shall never lack a successor on the throne of Israel.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you turn aside from following me, you or your children, and do not keep my commandments and my statutes that I have set before you but go and serve other gods and worship them,
speaker: Narrator

text: then I will cut Israel off from the land that I have given them, and the house that I have consecrated for my name I will cast out of my sight, and Israel will become a proverb and a taunt among all peoples.
speaker: Narrator

text: This house will become a heap of ruins; everyone passing by it will be astonished and will hiss, and they will say, ‘Why has the Lord done such a thing to this land and to this house?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they will say, ‘Because they abandoned the Lord their God, who brought their ancestors out of the land of Egypt, and embraced other gods, worshiping them and serving them; therefore the Lord brought this disaster upon them.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: At the end of twenty years, in which Solomon had built the two houses, the house of the Lord and the king’s house,
speaker: Narrator

text: King Hiram of Tyre having supplied Solomon with cedar and cypress timber and gold, as much as he desired, King Solomon gave to Hiram twenty cities in the land of Galilee.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when Hiram came from Tyre to see the cities that Solomon had given him, they did not please him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore he said, “What kind of cities are these that you have given me, my brother?” So they are called the land of Cabul to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Hiram had sent to the king one hundred twenty talents of gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the account of the forced labor that King Solomon conscripted to build the house of the Lord and his own house, the Millo and the wall of Jerusalem, Hazor, Megiddo, Gezer
speaker: Narrator

text: (Pharaoh king of Egypt had gone up and captured Gezer and burned it down, had killed the Canaanites who lived in the city, and had given it as dowry to his daughter, Solomon’s wife;
speaker: Narrator

text: so Solomon rebuilt Gezer), Lower Beth-horon,
speaker: Narrator

text: Baalath, Tadmor in the wilderness, within the land,
speaker: Narrator

text: as well as all of Solomon’s storage cities, the cities for his chariots, the cities for his cavalry, and whatever Solomon desired to build in Jerusalem, in Lebanon, and in all the land of his dominion.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people who were left of the Amorites, the Hittites, the Perizzites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites, who were not of the people of Israel—
speaker: Narrator

text: their descendants who were still left in the land, whom the Israelites were unable to destroy completely—these Solomon conscripted for slave labor, and so they are to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: But of the Israelites Solomon made no slaves; they were the soldiers; they were his officials, his commanders, his captains, and the commanders of his chariotry and cavalry.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the chief officers who were over Solomon’s work: five hundred fifty who had charge of the people who carried on the work.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Pharaoh’s daughter went up from the city of David to her own house that Solomon had built for her; then he built the Millo.
speaker: Narrator

text: Three times a year Solomon used to offer up burnt offerings and sacrifices of well-being on the altar that he built for the Lord, offering incense before the Lord. So he completed the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Solomon built a fleet of ships at Ezion-geber, which is near Eloth on the shore of the Red Sea, in the land of Edom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hiram sent his servants with the fleet, sailors who were familiar with the sea, together with the servants of Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went to Ophir and imported from there four hundred twenty talents of gold that they delivered to King Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the queen of Sheba heard of the fame of Solomon (fame due to the name of the Lord), she came to test him with riddles.
speaker: Narrator

text: She came to Jerusalem with a very great retinue, with camels bearing spices and very much gold and precious stones, and when she came to Solomon, she told him all that was on her mind.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon answered all her questions; there was nothing hidden from the king that he could not explain to her.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the queen of Sheba had observed all the wisdom of Solomon, the house that he had built,
speaker: Narrator

text: the food of his table, the seating of his officials, and the attendance of his servants, their clothing, his valets, and his burnt offerings that he offered at the house of the Lord, it took her breath away.
speaker: Narrator

text: So she said to the king, “The report was true that I heard in my own land of your accomplishments and of your wisdom,
speaker: Narrator

text: but I did not believe the reports until I came and my own eyes saw it. Not even half had been told me; your wisdom and prosperity far surpass the report that I had heard.
speaker: Narrator

text: Happy are your wives! Happy are these your servants who continually attend you and hear your wisdom!
speaker: Narrator

text: Blessed be the Lord your God, who has delighted in you and set you on the throne of Israel! Because the Lord loved Israel forever, he has made you king to execute justice and righteousness.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she gave the king one hundred twenty talents of gold, a great quantity of spices, and precious stones; never again did spices come in such quantity as that which the queen of Sheba gave to King Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, the fleet of Hiram, which carried gold from Ophir, brought from Ophir a great quantity of almug wood and precious stones.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the almug wood the king made supports for the house of the Lord and for the king’s house, lyres also and harps for the singers; no such almug wood has come or been seen to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, King Solomon gave to the queen of Sheba every desire that she expressed, as well as what he gave her out of Solomon’s royal bounty. Then she returned to her own land with her servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: The weight of gold that came to Solomon in one year was six hundred sixty-six talents of gold,
speaker: Narrator

text: besides that which came from the traders and from the business of the merchants and from all the kings of Arabia and the governors of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Solomon made two hundred large shields of beaten gold; six hundred shekels of gold went into each large shield.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made three hundred shields of beaten gold; three minas of gold went into each shield; and the king put them in the House of the Forest of Lebanon.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king also made a great ivory throne and overlaid it with the finest gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: The throne had six steps. The top of the throne was rounded in the back, and on each side of the seat were arm rests and two lions standing beside the arm rests,
speaker: Narrator

text: while twelve lions were standing, one on each end of a step on the six steps. Nothing like it was ever made in any kingdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: All King Solomon’s drinking vessels were of gold, and all the vessels of the House of the Forest of Lebanon were of pure gold; none were of silver—it was not considered as anything in the days of Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the king had a fleet of ships of Tarshish at sea with the fleet of Hiram. Once every three years the fleet of ships of Tarshish used to come bringing gold, silver, ivory, apes, and peacocks.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus King Solomon excelled all the kings of the earth in riches and in wisdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: The whole earth sought the presence of Solomon to hear his wisdom, which God had put into his mind.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every one of them brought a present, objects of silver and gold, garments, weaponry, spices, horses, and mules, so much year by year.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon gathered together chariots and horses; he had fourteen hundred chariots and twelve thousand horses, which he stationed in the chariot cities and with the king in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king made silver as common in Jerusalem as stone, and he made cedar as plentiful as the sycamores of the Shephelah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon’s import of horses was from Egypt and Kue, and the king’s traders received them from Kue at a price.
speaker: Narrator

text: A chariot could be imported from Egypt for six hundred shekels of silver and a horse for one hundred fifty, so through the king’s traders they were exported to all the kings of the Hittites and the kings of Aram.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Solomon loved many foreign women along with the daughter of Pharaoh: Moabite, Ammonite, Edomite, Sidonian, and Hittite women,
speaker: Narrator

text: from the nations concerning which the Lord had said to the Israelites, “You shall not enter into marriage with them, neither shall they with you, for they will surely incline your heart to follow their gods.” Solomon clung to these in love.
speaker: Narrator

text: Among his wives were seven hundred princesses and three hundred concubines, and his wives turned away his heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: For when Solomon was old, his wives turned away his heart after other gods, and his heart was not true to the Lord his God, as was the heart of his father David.
speaker: Narrator

text: For Solomon followed Astarte the goddess of the Sidonians and Milcom the abomination of the Ammonites.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Solomon did what was evil in the sight of the Lord and did not completely follow the Lord, as his father David had done.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Solomon built a high place for Chemosh the abomination of Moab and for Molech the abomination of the Ammonites on the mountain east of Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did the same for all his foreign wives who offered incense and sacrificed to their gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord was angry with Solomon because his heart had turned away from the Lord, the God of Israel, who had appeared to him twice
speaker: Narrator

text: and had commanded him concerning this matter, that he should not follow other gods, but he did not observe what the Lord had commanded.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore the Lord said to Solomon, “Since this has been your mind and you have not kept my covenant and my statutes that I have commanded you, I will surely tear the kingdom from you and give it to your servant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet for the sake of your father David I will not do it in your lifetime; I will tear it out of the hand of your son.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will not, however, tear away the entire kingdom; I will give one tribe to your son for the sake of my servant David and for the sake of Jerusalem, which I have chosen.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord raised up an adversary against Solomon, Hadad the Edomite; he was of the royal house in Edom.
speaker: Narrator

text: For when David was destroying Edom and Joab the commander of the army went up to bury the dead, he killed every male in Edom
speaker: Narrator

text: (for Joab and all Israel remained there six months until he had eliminated every male in Edom),
speaker: Narrator

text: but Hadad fled to Egypt with some Edomites who were servants of his father. He was a young boy at that time.
speaker: Narrator

text: They set out from Midian and came to Paran; they took people with them from Paran and came to Egypt, to Pharaoh king of Egypt, who gave him a house, assigned him an allowance of food, and gave him land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hadad found great favor in the sight of Pharaoh, so that he gave him his sister-in-law for a wife, the sister of Queen Tahpenes.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sister of Tahpenes gave birth by him to his son Genubath, whom Tahpenes weaned in Pharaoh’s house; Genubath was in Pharaoh’s house among the children of Pharaoh.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Hadad heard in Egypt that David slept with his ancestors and that Joab the commander of the army was dead, Hadad said to Pharaoh, “Let me depart, that I may go to my own country.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Pharaoh said to him, “What do you lack with me that you now seek to go to your own country?” And he said, “No, do let me go.”
speaker: Narrator

text: God raised up another adversary against Solomon, Rezon son of Eliada, who had fled from his master, King Hadadezer of Zobah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He gathered followers around him and became leader of a marauding band, after the killing by David; they went to Damascus, settled there, and made him king in Damascus.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was an adversary of Israel all the days of Solomon, making trouble as Hadad did; he despised Israel and reigned over Aram.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeroboam son of Nebat, an Ephraimite of Zeredah, a servant of Solomon, whose mother’s name was Zeruah, a widow, rebelled against the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: The following was the reason he rebelled against the king. Solomon built the Millo and closed up the gap in the wall of the city of his father David.
speaker: Narrator

text: The man Jeroboam was very able, and when Solomon saw that the young man was industrious, he gave him charge over all the forced labor of the house of Joseph.
speaker: Narrator

text: About that time, when Jeroboam was leaving Jerusalem, the prophet Ahijah the Shilonite found him on the road. Ahijah had clothed himself with a new garment. The two of them were alone in the open country
speaker: Narrator

text: when Ahijah laid hold of the new garment he was wearing and tore it into twelve pieces.
speaker: Narrator

text: He then said to Jeroboam, “Take for yourself ten pieces, for thus says the Lord, the God of Israel: See, I am about to tear the kingdom from the hand of Solomon and will give you ten tribes.
speaker: Narrator

text: One tribe will remain his, for the sake of my servant David and for the sake of Jerusalem, the city that I have chosen out of all the tribes of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is because he has forsaken me, worshiped Astarte the goddess of the Sidonians, Chemosh the god of Moab, and Milcom the god of the Ammonites, and has not walked in my ways, doing what is right in my sight and keeping my statutes and my ordinances, as his father David did.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless, I will not take the whole kingdom away from him but will make him ruler all the days of his life, for the sake of my servant David whom I chose and who did keep my commandments and my statutes,
speaker: Narrator

text: but I will take the kingdom away from his son and give it to you—that is, the ten tribes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet to his son I will give one tribe, so that my servant David may always have a lamp before me in Jerusalem, the city where I have chosen to put my name.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will take you, and you shall reign over all that your soul desires; you shall be king over Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you will listen to all that I command you, walk in my ways, and do what is right in my sight by keeping my statutes and my commandments, as David my servant did, I will be with you and will build you an enduring house, as I built for David, and I will give Israel to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this reason I will punish the descendants of David, but not forever.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon sought therefore to kill Jeroboam, but Jeroboam promptly fled to Egypt, to King Shishak of Egypt, and remained in Egypt until the death of Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the acts of Solomon, all that he did as well as his wisdom, are they not written in the Book of the Acts of Solomon?
speaker: Narrator

text: The time that Solomon reigned in Jerusalem over all Israel was forty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon slept with his ancestors and was buried in the city of his father David, and his son Rehoboam succeeded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rehoboam went to Shechem, for all Israel had come to Shechem to make him king.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jeroboam son of Nebat heard of it (for he was still in Egypt, where he had fled from King Solomon), then Jeroboam remained in Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they sent and called him, and Jeroboam and all the assembly of Israel came and said to Rehoboam,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Your father made our yoke heavy. Now, therefore, lighten the hard service of your father and his heavy yoke that he placed on us, and we will serve you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “Go away for three days, then come again to me.” So the people went away.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then King Rehoboam took counsel with the older men who had attended his father Solomon while he was still alive, saying, “How do you advise me to answer this people?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They answered him, “If you will be a servant to this people today and serve them and speak good words to them when you answer them, then they will be your servants forever.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he disregarded the advice that the older men gave him and consulted with the young men who had grown up with him and now attended him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “What do you advise that we answer this people who have said to me, ‘Lighten the yoke that your father put on us’?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The young men who had grown up with him said to him, “Thus you should say to this people who spoke to you, ‘Your father made our yoke heavy, but you must lighten it for us’; thus you should say to them, ‘My little finger is thicker than my father’s loins.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, whereas my father laid on you a heavy yoke, I will add to your yoke. My father disciplined you with whips, but I will discipline you with scorpions.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jeroboam and all the people came to Rehoboam the third day, as the king had said, “Come to me again the third day.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king answered the people harshly. He disregarded the advice that the older men had given him
speaker: Narrator

text: and spoke to them according to the advice of the young men, “My father made your yoke heavy, but I will add to your yoke; my father disciplined you with whips, but I will discipline you with scorpions.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king did not listen to the people because it was a turn of affairs brought about by the Lord to fulfill his word that the Lord had spoken by Ahijah the Shilonite to Jeroboam son of Nebat.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When all Israel saw that the king would not listen to them, the people answered the king,
“What share do we have in David?
    We have no inheritance in the son of Jesse.
To your tents, O Israel!
    Look now to your own house, O David.”
So Israel went away to their tents.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Rehoboam reigned over the Israelites who were living in the towns of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: When King Rehoboam sent Adoram, who was taskmaster over the forced labor, all Israel stoned him to death. King Rehoboam then hurriedly mounted his chariot to flee to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Israel has been in rebellion against the house of David to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all Israel heard that Jeroboam had returned, they sent and called him to the assembly and made him king over all Israel. There was no one who followed the house of David except the tribe of Judah alone.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Rehoboam came to Jerusalem, he assembled all the house of Judah and the tribe of Benjamin, one hundred eighty thousand chosen troops, to fight against the house of Israel, to restore the kingdom to Rehoboam son of Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the word of God came to Shemaiah the man of God:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Say to King Rehoboam of Judah, son of Solomon, and to all the house of Judah and Benjamin, and to the rest of the people:
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus says the Lord: You shall not go up or fight against your kindred the people of Israel. Let everyone go home, for this thing is from me.” So they heeded the word of the Lord and went home again, according to the word of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jeroboam built Shechem in the hill country of Ephraim and resided there; he went out from there and built Penuel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jeroboam said to himself, “Now the kingdom may well revert to the house of David.
speaker: Narrator

text: If this people continues to go up to offer sacrifices in the house of the Lord at Jerusalem, the heart of this people will turn again to their master, King Rehoboam of Judah; they will kill me and return to King Rehoboam of Judah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king took counsel and made two calves of gold. He said to the people, “You have gone up to Jerusalem long enough. Here are your gods, O Israel, who brought you up out of the land of Egypt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He set one in Bethel, and the other he put in Dan.
speaker: Narrator

text: And this thing became a sin, for the people went to worship before the one at Bethel and before the other as far as Dan.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also made houses on high places and appointed priests from among all the people who were not Levites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeroboam appointed a festival on the fifteenth day of the eighth month like the festival that was in Judah, and he offered sacrifices on the altar; so he did in Bethel, sacrificing to the calves that he had made. And he placed in Bethel the priests of the high places that he had made.
speaker: Narrator

text: He went up to the altar that he had made in Bethel on the fifteenth day in the eighth month, in the month that he had selected on his own; he appointed a festival for the people of Israel, and he went up to the altar to offer incense.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man of God came out of Judah by the word of the Lord to Bethel, while Jeroboam was standing by the altar to offer incense.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he cried out against the altar by the word of the Lord and said, “O altar, altar, thus says the Lord: A son shall be born to the house of David, Josiah by name, and he shall sacrifice on you the priests of the high places who offer incense on you, and human bones shall be burned on you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He gave a sign the same day, saying, “This is the sign that the Lord has spoken: The altar shall be torn down, and the ashes that are on it shall be poured out.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the king heard what the man of God cried out against the altar at Bethel, Jeroboam stretched out his hand from the altar, saying, “Seize him!” But the hand that he stretched out against him withered so that he could not draw it back to himself.
