speaker: Narrator

text: The altar also was torn down, and the ashes poured out from the altar, according to the sign that the man of God had given by the word of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said to the man of God, “Entreat now the favor of the Lord your God, and pray for me, so that my hand may be restored to me.” So the man of God entreated the Lord, and the king’s hand was restored to him and became as it was before.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king said to the man of God, “Come home with me and dine, and I will give you a gift.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the man of God said to the king, “If you give me half your kingdom, I will not go in with you, nor will I eat food or drink water in this place.
speaker: Narrator

text: For thus I was commanded by the word of the Lord: ‘You shall not eat food, or drink water, or return by the way that you came.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he went another way and did not return by the way that he had come to Bethel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there lived an old prophet in Bethel. One of his sons came and told him all that the man of God had done that day in Bethel; the words also that he had spoken to the king, they told to their father.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their father said to them, “Which way did he go?” And his sons showed him the way that the man of God who came from Judah had gone.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to his sons, “Saddle a donkey for me.” So they saddled a donkey for him, and he mounted it.
speaker: Narrator

text: He went after the man of God and found him sitting under an oak tree. He said to him, “Are you the man of God who came from Judah?” He answered, “I am.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to him, “Come home with me and eat some food.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he said, “I cannot return with you or go in with you, nor will I eat food or drink water with you in this place,
speaker: Narrator

text: for it was said to me by the word of the Lord, ‘You shall not eat food or drink water there or return by the way that you came.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the other said to him, “I also am a prophet as you are, and an angel spoke to me by the word of the Lord, ‘Bring him back with you into your house so that he may eat food and drink water.’ ” But he was deceiving him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the man of God went back with him and ate food and drank water in his house.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they were sitting at the table, the word of the Lord came to the prophet who had brought him back,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he cried out to the man of God who came from Judah, “Thus says the Lord: Because you have disobeyed the word of the Lord and have not kept the commandment that the Lord your God commanded you
speaker: Narrator

text: but have come back and have eaten food and drunk water in the place of which he said to you, ‘Eat no food, and drink no water,’ your body shall not come to your ancestral tomb.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After the man of God had eaten food and had drunk, they saddled for him a donkey belonging to the prophet who had brought him back.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then as he went away, a lion met him on the road and killed him. His body was thrown in the road, and the donkey stood beside it; the lion also stood beside the body.
speaker: Narrator

text: People passed by and saw the body thrown in the road, with the lion standing by the body. And they came and told it in the town where the old prophet lived.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the prophet who had brought him back from the way heard of it, he said, “It is the man of God who disobeyed the word of the Lord; therefore the Lord has given him to the lion, which has torn him and killed him according to the word that the Lord spoke to him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to his sons, “Saddle a donkey for me.” So they saddled one,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he went and found the body thrown in the road, with the donkey and the lion standing beside the body. The lion had not eaten the body or attacked the donkey.
speaker: Narrator

text: The prophet took up the body of the man of God, laid it on the donkey, and brought it back to the city to mourn and to bury him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He laid the body in his own grave, and they mourned over him, saying, “Alas, my brother!”
speaker: Narrator

text: After he had buried him, he said to his sons, “When I die, bury me in the grave in which the man of God is buried; lay my bones beside his bones.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the saying that he proclaimed by the word of the Lord against the altar in Bethel and against all the houses of the high places that are in the cities of Samaria shall surely come to pass.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Even after this event Jeroboam did not turn from his evil way but made priests for the high places again from among all the people; any who wanted to be priests he consecrated for the high places.
speaker: Narrator

text: This matter became sin to the house of Jeroboam, so as to cut it off and to destroy it from the face of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time Abijah son of Jeroboam fell sick.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeroboam said to his wife, “Go, disguise yourself so that it will not be known that you are the wife of Jeroboam, and go to Shiloh, for the prophet Ahijah is there, who said of me that I should be king over this people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take with you ten loaves, some cakes, and a jar of honey, and go to him; he will tell you what shall happen to the child.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeroboam’s wife did so; she set out and went to Shiloh and came to the house of Ahijah. Now Ahijah could not see, for his eyes were dim because of his age.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord said to Ahijah, “The wife of Jeroboam is coming to inquire of you concerning her son, for he is sick. Thus and thus you shall say to her when she comes. She will pretend to be another woman.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But when Ahijah heard the sound of her feet as she came in at the door, he said, “Come in, wife of Jeroboam; why do you pretend to be another? For I am charged with heavy tidings for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go, tell Jeroboam, ‘Thus says the Lord, the God of Israel: Because I exalted you from among the people, made you leader over my people Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text: and tore the kingdom away from the house of David to give it to you, yet you have not been like my servant David, who kept my commandments and followed me with all his heart, doing only that which was right in my sight,
speaker: Narrator

text: but you have done evil above all those who were before you and have gone and made for yourself other gods and cast images, provoking me to anger, and have thrust me behind your back,
speaker: Narrator

text: therefore I will bring evil upon the house of Jeroboam. I will cut off from Jeroboam every male, both bond and free in Israel, and will consume the house of Jeroboam, just as one burns up dung until it is all gone.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone belonging to Jeroboam who dies in the city the dogs shall eat, and anyone who dies in the open country the birds of the air shall eat, for the Lord has spoken.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore set out, go to your house. When your feet enter the city, the child shall die.
speaker: Narrator

text: All Israel shall mourn for him and bury him, for he alone of Jeroboam’s family shall come to the grave, because in him there is found something pleasing to the Lord, the God of Israel, in the house of Jeroboam.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover the Lord will raise up for himself a king over Israel who shall cut off the house of Jeroboam today, even right now!
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord will strike Israel as a reed is shaken in the water; he will root up Israel out of this good land that he gave to their ancestors and scatter them beyond the Euphrates, because they have made their sacred poles, provoking the Lord to anger.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will give Israel up because of the sins of Jeroboam, which he sinned and which he caused Israel to commit.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jeroboam’s wife got up and went away, and she came to Tirzah. As she came to the threshold of the house, the child died.
speaker: Narrator

text: All Israel buried him and mourned for him, according to the word of the Lord that he spoke by his servant the prophet Ahijah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the acts of Jeroboam, how he warred and how he reigned, are written in the Book of the Annals of the Kings of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The time that Jeroboam reigned was twenty-two years; then he slept with his ancestors, and his son Nadab succeeded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Rehoboam son of Solomon reigned in Judah. Rehoboam was forty-one years old when he began to reign, and he reigned seventeen years in Jerusalem, the city that the Lord had chosen out of all the tribes of Israel, to put his name there. His mother’s name was Naamah the Ammonite.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah did what was evil in the sight of the Lord; they provoked him to jealousy with their sins that they committed, more than all that their ancestors had done.
speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

text: now I will send my servants to you tomorrow about this time, and they shall search your house and the houses of your servants and lay hands on whatever pleases them and take it away.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king of Israel called all the elders of the land and said, “Look now! See how this man is seeking trouble, for he sent to me for my wives, my children, my silver, and my gold, and I did not refuse him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the elders and all the people said to him, “Do not listen or consent.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he said to the messengers of Ben-hadad, “Tell my lord the king: All that you first demanded of your servant I will do, but this thing I cannot do.” The messengers left and brought him word again.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ben-hadad sent to him and said, “The gods do so to me and more also, if the dust of Samaria will provide a handful for each of the people who follow me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Israel answered, “Enough! One who puts on armor should not brag like one who takes it off.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Ben-hadad heard this message—now he had been drinking with the kings in the booths—he said to his men, “Take your positions!” And they took their positions against the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then a certain prophet came up to King Ahab of Israel and said, “Thus says the Lord: Have you seen all this great multitude? Look, I will give it into your hand today, and you shall know that I am the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahab said, “By whom?” He said, “Thus says the Lord: By the young men who serve the district governors.” Then he said, “Who shall begin the battle?” He answered, “You.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he mustered the young men who served the district governors, two hundred thirty-two; after them he mustered all the people of Israel, seven thousand.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went out at noon, while Ben-hadad was drinking himself drunk in the booths, he and the thirty-two kings allied with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The young men who served the district governors went out first. Ben-hadad had sent out scouts, and they reported to him, “Men have come out from Samaria.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “If they have come out for peace, take them alive; if they have come out for war, take them alive.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But these had already come out of the city: the young men who served the district governors and the army that followed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each killed his man; the Arameans fled, and Israel pursued them, but King Ben-hadad of Aram escaped on a horse with the cavalry.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Israel went out, attacked the horses and chariots, and inflicted a massive defeat on the Arameans.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the prophet approached the king of Israel and said to him, “Come, strengthen yourself, and consider well what you have to do, for in the spring the king of Aram will come up against you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The servants of the king of Aram said to him, “Their gods are gods of the hills, so they were stronger than we, but let us fight against them in the plain, and surely we shall be stronger than they.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also do this: remove the kings, each from his post, and put commanders in place of them;
speaker: Narrator

text: and muster an army like the army that you have lost, horse for horse, and chariot for chariot; then we will fight against them in the plain, and surely we shall be stronger than they.” He heeded their voice and did so.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the spring Ben-hadad mustered the Arameans and went up to Aphek to fight against Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the Israelites had been mustered and provisioned, they went out to engage them; the people of Israel encamped opposite them like two little flocks of goats, while the Arameans filled the country.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man of God approached and said to the king of Israel, “Thus says the Lord: Because the Arameans have said, ‘The Lord is a god of the hills, but he is not a god of the valleys,’ therefore I will give all this great multitude into your hand, and you shall know that I am the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They encamped opposite one another seven days. Then on the seventh day the battle began; the Israelites killed one hundred thousand Aramean foot soldiers in one day.
speaker: Narrator

The rest fled into the city of Aphek, and the wall fell on twenty-seven thousand men who were left.

speaker: Narrator

text: His servants said to him, “Look, we have heard that the kings of the house of Israel are merciful kings; let us put sackcloth around our waists and ropes on our heads, and go out to the king of Israel; perhaps he will spare your life.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they tied sackcloth around their waists, put ropes on their heads, went to the king of Israel, and said, “Your servant Ben-hadad says, ‘Please let me live.’ ” And he said, “Is he still alive? He is my brother.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the men were watching for an omen; they quickly took it up from him and said, “Yes, Ben-hadad is your brother.” Then he said, “Go and bring him.” So Ben-hadad came out to him, and he had him come up into the chariot.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ben-hadad said to him, “I will restore the towns that my father took from your father, and you may establish bazaars for yourself in Damascus, as my father did in Samaria.” The king of Israel responded, “I will let you go on those terms.” So he made a treaty with him and let him go.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the command of the Lord a certain member of a company of prophets said to another, “Strike me!” But the man refused to strike him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to him, “Because you have not obeyed the voice of the Lord, as soon as you have left me, a lion will kill you.” And when he had left him, a lion met him and killed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he found another man and said, “Strike me!” So the man hit him, striking and wounding him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the prophet departed and waited for the king along the road, disguising himself with a bandage over his eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the king passed by, he cried to the king and said, “Your servant went out into the thick of the battle; then a soldier turned and brought a man to me and said, ‘Guard this man; if he is missing, your life shall be given for his life, or else you shall pay a talent of silver.’
speaker: Narrator

text: While your servant was busy here and there, he was gone.” The king of Israel said to him, “So shall your judgment be; you yourself have decided it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he quickly took the bandage away from his eyes. The king of Israel recognized him as one of the prophets.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to him, “Thus says the Lord: Because you have let the man go whom I had devoted to destruction, therefore your life shall be for his life and your people for his people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Israel set out toward home, resentful and sullen, and came to Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later the following events took place: Naboth the Jezreelite had a vineyard in Jezreel beside the palace of King Ahab of Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Ahab said to Naboth, “Give me your vineyard, so that I may have it for a vegetable garden, because it is near my house; I will give you a better vineyard for it, or, if it seems good to you, I will give you its value in money.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Naboth said to Ahab, “The Lord forbid that I should give you my ancestral inheritance.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahab went home resentful and sullen because of what Naboth the Jezreelite had said to him, for he had said, “I will not give you my ancestral inheritance.” He lay down on his bed, turned away his face, and would not eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: His wife Jezebel came to him and said, “Why are you so depressed that you will not eat?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to her, “Because I spoke to Naboth the Jezreelite and said to him, ‘Give me your vineyard for money, or if you prefer, I will give you another vineyard for it,’ but he answered, ‘I will not give you my vineyard.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: His wife Jezebel said to him, “Do you now govern Israel? Get up, eat some food, and be cheerful; I will give you the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So she wrote letters in Ahab’s name and sealed them with his seal; she sent the letters to the elders and the nobles who lived with Naboth in his city.
speaker: Narrator

text: She wrote in the letters, “Proclaim a fast, and seat Naboth at the head of the assembly;
speaker: Narrator

text: seat two scoundrels opposite him, and have them bring a charge against him, saying, ‘You have cursed God and the king.’ Then take him out and stone him to death.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of his city, the elders and the nobles who lived in his city, did as Jezebel had sent word to them. Just as it was written in the letters that she had sent to them,
speaker: Narrator

text: they proclaimed a fast and seated Naboth at the head of the assembly.
speaker: Narrator

text: The two scoundrels came in and sat opposite him, and the scoundrels brought a charge against Naboth in the presence of the people, saying, “Naboth cursed God and the king.” So they took him outside the city and stoned him to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they sent to Jezebel, saying, “Naboth has been stoned; he is dead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as Jezebel heard that Naboth had been stoned and was dead, Jezebel said to Ahab, “Go, take possession of the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite, which he refused to give you for money, for Naboth is not alive but dead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as Ahab heard that Naboth was dead, Ahab set out to go down to the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite, to take possession of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the word of the Lord came to Elijah the Tishbite, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go down to meet King Ahab of Israel, who rules in Samaria; he is now in the vineyard of Naboth, where he has gone to take possession.
speaker: Narrator

text: You shall say to him: Thus says the Lord: Have you killed and also taken possession? You shall say to him: Thus says the Lord: In the place where dogs licked up the blood of Naboth, dogs will also lick up your blood.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahab said to Elijah, “Have you found me, O my enemy?” He answered, “I have found you. Because you have sold yourself to do what is evil in the sight of the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: I will bring disaster on you; I will consume you and will cut off from Ahab every male, bond or free, in Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text: and I will make your house like the house of Jeroboam son of Nebat and like the house of Baasha son of Ahijah, because you have provoked me to anger and have caused Israel to sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also concerning Jezebel the Lord said: The dogs shall eat Jezebel within the bounds of Jezreel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone belonging to Ahab who dies in the city the dogs shall eat, and anyone of his who dies in the open country the birds of the air shall eat.”
speaker: Narrator

text: (Indeed, there was no one like Ahab, who sold himself to do what was evil in the sight of the Lord, urged on by his wife Jezebel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He acted most abominably in going after idols, as the Amorites had done, whom the Lord had driven out before the Israelites.)
speaker: Narrator

text: When Ahab heard those words, he tore his clothes and put sackcloth over his bare flesh; he fasted, lay in the sackcloth, and went about dejectedly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the word of the Lord came to Elijah the Tishbite,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Have you seen how Ahab has humbled himself before me? Because he has humbled himself before me, I will not bring the disaster in his days, but in his son’s days I will bring the disaster on his house.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For three years Aram and Israel continued without war.
speaker: Narrator

text: But in the third year King Jehoshaphat of Judah came down to the king of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Israel said to his servants, “Do you know that Ramoth-gilead belongs to us, yet we are doing nothing to take it out of the hand of the king of Aram?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to Jehoshaphat, “Will you go with me to battle at Ramoth-gilead?” Jehoshaphat replied to the king of Israel, “I am as you are; my people are your people; my horses are your horses.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jehoshaphat also said to the king of Israel, “Inquire first for the word of the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king of Israel gathered the prophets together, about four hundred of them, and said to them, “Shall I go to battle against Ramoth-gilead, or shall I refrain?” They said, “Go up, for the Lord will give it into the hand of the king.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jehoshaphat said, “Is there no other prophet of the Lord here of whom we may inquire?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, “There is still one other by whom we may inquire of the Lord, Micaiah son of Imlah, but I hate him, for he never prophesies anything favorable about me but only disaster.” Jehoshaphat said, “Let the king not say such a thing.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king of Israel summoned an officer and said, “Bring quickly Micaiah son of Imlah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the king of Israel and King Jehoshaphat of Judah were sitting on their thrones, arrayed in their robes, at the threshing floor at the entrance of the gate of Samaria, and all the prophets were prophesying before them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zedekiah son of Chenaanah made for himself horns of iron, and he said, “Thus says the Lord: With these you shall gore the Arameans until they are destroyed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: All the prophets were prophesying the same and saying, “Go up to Ramoth-gilead and triumph; the Lord will give it into the hand of the king.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The messenger who had gone to summon Micaiah said to him, “Look, the words of the prophets with one accord are favorable to the king; let your word be like the word of one of them, and speak favorably.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Micaiah said, “As the Lord lives, whatever the Lord says to me, that I will speak.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When he had come to the king, the king said to him, “Micaiah, shall we go to Ramoth-gilead to battle, or shall we refrain?” He answered him, “Go up and triumph; the Lord will give it into the hand of the king.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the king said to him, “How many times must I make you swear to tell me nothing but the truth in the name of the Lord?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Micaiah said, “I saw all Israel scattered on the mountains like sheep that have no shepherd, and the Lord said, ‘These have no master; let each one go home in peace.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, “Did I not tell you that he would not prophesy anything favorable about me but only disaster?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Micaiah said, “Therefore hear the word of the Lord: I saw the Lord sitting on his throne, with all the host of heaven standing beside him to the right and to the left of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said, ‘Who will entice Ahab, so that he may go up and fall at Ramoth-gilead?’ Then one said one thing, and another said another,
speaker: Narrator

text: until a certain spirit came forward and stood before the Lord, saying, ‘I will entice him.’
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘How?’ the Lord asked him. He replied, ‘I will go out and be a lying spirit in the mouth of all his prophets.’ Then the Lord said, ‘You are to entice him, and you shall succeed; go out and do it.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So you see, the Lord has put a lying spirit in the mouth of all these your prophets; the Lord has decreed disaster for you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Zedekiah son of Chenaanah came up to Micaiah, slapped him on the cheek, and said, “Which way did the spirit of the Lord pass from me to speak to you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Micaiah replied, “You will find out on that day when you go in to hide in an inner chamber.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Israel then ordered, “Take Micaiah, and return him to Amon the governor of the city and to Joash the king’s son,
speaker: Narrator

text: and say: Thus says the king: Put this fellow in prison, and feed him on reduced rations of bread and water until I come in peace.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Micaiah said, “If you return in peace, the Lord has not spoken by me.” And he said, “Hear, you peoples, all of you!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king of Israel and King Jehoshaphat of Judah went up to Ramoth-gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, “I will disguise myself and go into battle, but you wear your robes.” So the king of Israel disguised himself and went into battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the king of Aram had commanded the thirty-two captains of his chariots, “Fight with no one small or great but only with the king of Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the captains of the chariots saw Jehoshaphat, they said, “It is surely the king of Israel.” So they turned to fight against him, and Jehoshaphat cried out.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the captains of the chariots saw that it was not the king of Israel, they turned back from pursuing him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But a certain man drew his bow and unknowingly struck the king of Israel between the scale armor and the breastplate; so he said to the driver of his chariot, “Turn around and carry me out of the battle, for I am wounded.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The battle grew hot that day, and the king was propped up in his chariot facing the Arameans until at evening he died; the blood from the wound had flowed into the bottom of the chariot.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then about sunset a shout went through the army, “Every man to his city, and every man to his country!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king died and was brought to Samaria; they buried the king in Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: They washed the chariot by the pool of Samaria; the dogs licked up his blood, and the prostitutes washed themselves in it, according to the word of the Lord that he had spoken.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the acts of Ahab and all that he did and the ivory house that he built and all the cities that he built, are they not written in the Book of the Annals of the Kings of Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text: So Ahab slept with his ancestors, and his son Ahaziah succeeded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoshaphat son of Asa began to reign over Judah in the fourth year of King Ahab of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoshaphat was thirty-five years old when he began to reign, and he reigned twenty-five years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Azubah daughter of Shilhi.
speaker: Narrator

text: He walked in all the way of his father Asa; he did not turn aside from it, doing what was right in the sight of the Lord, yet the high places were not taken away, and the people still sacrificed and offered incense on the high places.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoshaphat also made peace with the king of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the acts of Jehoshaphat and his power that he showed and how he waged war, are they not written in the Book of the Annals of the Kings of Judah?
speaker: Narrator

text: The remnant of the illicit priests who remained from the days of his father Asa, he purged from the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was no king in Edom; a deputy was king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoshaphat made ships of the Tarshish type to go to Ophir for gold, but they did not go, for the ships were wrecked at Ezion-geber.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Ahaziah son of Ahab said to Jehoshaphat, “Let my servants go with your servants in the ships,” but Jehoshaphat was not willing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoshaphat slept with his ancestors and was buried with his ancestors in the city of his father David; his son Jehoram succeeded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahaziah son of Ahab began to reign over Israel in Samaria in the seventeenth year of King Jehoshaphat of Judah; he reigned two years over Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did what was evil in the sight of the Lord and walked in the way of his father and mother and in the way of Jeroboam son of Nebat, who caused Israel to sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: He served Baal and worshiped him; he provoked the Lord, the God of Israel, to anger, just as his father had done.
